title: Washing Machine
description: There are certain times at which running your washing machine or tumble dryer can be more expensive
info: The most expensive time for you to wash or dry your clothes is between 4pm and 7pm, so try to avoid. You could also try washing less frequently, washing with colder temperature settings and skiping the ironing. SUPERTIP - Nobody likes ironing though do we?

title: Water / Boiler
description: Turning your combi boiler flow temperature down to 60°C could save you up to £100 a year
info: Flow temperature is the temperature of the water that your boiler sends to radiators. Reducing flow temperature is not the same as lowering your thermostat and will not noticeably reduce the temperature of your home but may increase the time it takes to reach the target temperature on your thermostat. If you are over 65, or have pre-existing health conditions, you may want to set a slightly higher flow temperature of 65°C to ensure your home warms more quickly.

title: Plug Sockets
description: Turning appliances off at the socket could save you up to £70 a year
info: Almost all electrical appliances in your home, such as computers, televisions, smart devices and video game consoles, draw power continuously unless unplugged. Leaving devices on standby could be costing you more money. Turn off the power switch at the socket or unplug appliances from the socket when they are not in use.

title: More Money Saving Tips
info: Click on the link for more money saving advice

title: Light
info: Switch to LED light bulbs. Traditional bulbs waste a lot of energy. Modern LEDs are the opposite, and also last longer so are less wasteful too. Try to remember to switch lights off when you dont need them. If you replace all the bulbs in your home with LED lights, you could reduce your carbon dioxide emissions by up to 40kg (50kg in NI) a year. This is equivalent to the carbon dioxide emitted by driving your car around 145 miles.

title: Radiators
description: Turning down radiators in rooms you arent using or use less could save you up to £70 a year
info: When youre not using rooms, turn radiator valves down to between 2.5 and 3 (roughly 18°C). While you are using a room, increase the temperature to a comfortable level by turning the valve up. Turning off radiators completely in rooms you are not using is less energy efficient as this means your boiler has to work harder to increase the temperature again than if kept at a low setting. People over 65, children under 5 and those with pre-existing health conditions are more vulnerable to cold temperatures. Make sure you are warm enough and have a minimum indoor temperature of 18°C to ensure you protect your health while maintaining comfort.

title: Computer
description: Turning appliances off at the socket could save you up to £70 a year
info: Almost all electrical appliances in your home, such as computers, televisions, smart devices and video game consoles, draw power continuously unless unplugged. Turn off the power switch at the socket or unplug appliances from the socket when they are not in use.

title: Get Active - Save Money
description: Running a car costs on average £3,727 per annum; a cycle, however, is just £396, if not less.
info: Fuel prices are at an all-time high, representing a significant outlay for car drivers

title: Tumble Dryer
info: There are some simple and effective ways that you can reduce your electricity bill and make your use of the tumble dryer in bad weather, more effective.  One of the best ways is not overload your machine. Good Housekeeping have a great article (link below) on many tips to help you increase the effectiveness of your use of this sometimes essential household appliance.

title: fridge
description: Fridge / freezer - how to make these more energy efficient
info: Make sure that your fridge is two thirds full. Not full to bursting, but not empty. Ensure that your fridge is running at the optimal temperature of 5 °C and -18 °C for freezer consumption.

title: Kettle
description: Boiling your kettle is among the top offenders of increased energy consumption in your home
info: Every time you boil your kettle with hardly any water, you are being charged at the full rate. Why not fill your kettle, boil the water, and then store that boiled water in a thermos flask to come back to later?  You could save over £300 from your energy bills per year by following the advice in the link.
